repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Rural Access
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Yemen Rural Access
            Program Phase 1 Project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            it has been generally observed that contract management is
            at present the main weakness of local contractors. This
            should be carefully considered when designing future
            projects in Yemen, especially when assessing the capacity of
            the local construction industry and estimating the
            contracts' implementation periods. The environment in
            Yemen is in general very difficult for contractors and small
            works in isolated rural areas are unlikely to be financially
            attractive, even for large Yemeni contractors, because of
            the high mobilization and administration costs of contracts
            and the high risks. The use of preliminary designs (and not
            final designs as was done for this project for two thirds of
            the contracts) should be limited as much as possible. Local
            consultation and participation in the design and
            implementation process have proved to be highly effective in
            making designs more relevant and in facilitating
            implementation. The experience of this project has shown
            that it is a rather complex exercise to set specific outcome
            targets and that it should be done on a case by case basis
            with a careful analysis of potential improvements.

repnme.cdata!: Yemen - Rural Access Improvement Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Access Improvement Program
            Project aims at improving the livelihood, and reducing the
            isolation of the rural population in Yemen. The components
            will: 1) test, and demonstrate new technical standards for
            rural access roads, selected as pilot projects in different
            Governorates with high poverty incidences. Supervision, and
            civil works will feature road width, and slope
            stabilization; bituminous surfacing; embankment design, and
            wadi hydrology; measures to prevent terrace destruction, and
            erosion; and, local participation/consultation in the
            planning process; 2) test rural accessibility in at least
            fifty km of village access roads, through planning methods
            for civil works, and construction supervision, and,
            consultations with beneficiaries will be conducted. It
            includes technical designs, and water harvesting techniques,
            with specific environmental measures; 3) establish
            participatory processes on rural access planning, and
            support the technical preparation work for civil works to be
            executed during the second phase of the project, including
            design studies, and bidding documents; 4) establish
            institutional frameworks, and capacity building to support
            the decentralized management of rural access improvements.
            Institutional arrangements will lay the foundation for
            revised technical, and environmental standards, and
            procedures, and, consolidate the national budget for rural
            roads, through training, workshops, and studies, as well as
            technical assistance; 5) finance supplemental operating
            costs, and equipment, including staff salaries, and
            vehicles; and, 6) finance the rehabilitation of the Al Ahmar
            - An Naqbah Road, including repair works, drainage
            improvements, and protection works.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Rural Access
            Improvement Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Access Improvement
            Project's Environmental Management Plan (EMP) concerns
            Phase I of the three-phased Adaptable Lending Program. The
            pilot roads in Phase I will be purposefully selected to
            minimize adverse environmental and social impacts and avoid
            resettlement and land acquisition. Four main issues have
            been identified to improve and create environmentally-sound
            technical designs: water harvesting on mountain roads to
            reduce road surface degradation, narrower platforms to avoid
            deep cuts into the mountainside, road surfacing to be
            stabilized on steep slopes to avoid erosion, slope
            stabilization on sections of the roads where slopes are
            unstable, and controlled disposal at designated sites of
            material cut from the hillside slopes. The project will
            address these issues by assisting the Government to revise
            the design standards for rural roads and try out new
            standards for rural roads. Specific measures to reduce
            potential impacts of physical works will be taken regarding
            the detailed design, construction tenders, construction
            process, and contractor performance monitoring. Contracts
            will contain requirements for proper management of
            construction waste; control measures for waste fuel, oil
            and, lubricants; reduction of noise and dust levels; and
            rehabilitation of areas used for construction detours and
            sites used to temporarily store construction materials.
            Contractors will be required to provide and maintain
            equipment with proper noise abatement controls.
